## How to Build a Basic Cardiac Monitor

### Table of Contents
- [Introduction](#introduction)
- [Materials/Tools](#materials-tools)
- [Step-by-Step Procedure](#step-by-step-procedure)
- [Tips and Considerations](#tips-and-considerations)
- [Troubleshooting](#troubleshooting)
- [Safety Measures](#safety-measures)
- [Common Mistakes to Avoid](#common-mistakes-to-avoid)
- [Summary and Key Takeaways](#summary-and-key-takeaways)

### Introduction
Building a basic cardiac monitor can be a valuable project for anyone interested in understanding and monitoring their heart rate. This guide will provide step-by-step instructions on how to build a simple cardiac monitor using readily available materials. By following these instructions, you will be able to create a device that can measure and display your heart rate in real-time.

### Materials/Tools
To build a basic cardiac monitor, you will need the following materials and tools:
- Arduino board
- Heart rate sensor module
- Breadboard
- Jumper wires
- LCD display module
- Potentiometer
- USB cable
- Computer with Arduino IDE installed

### Step-by-Step Procedure
1. Connect the Arduino board to your computer using the USB cable.
2. Launch the Arduino IDE on your computer.
3. Connect the heart rate sensor module to the Arduino board using jumper wires. Make sure to connect the appropriate pins according to the sensor's datasheet.
4. Connect the LCD display module to the Arduino board using jumper wires. Again, refer to the datasheet for the correct pin connections.
5. Connect the potentiometer to the LCD display module. This will be used to adjust the contrast of the display.
6. Open a new sketch in the Arduino IDE.
7. Import the necessary libraries for the heart rate sensor module and the LCD display module.
8. Write the code to initialize the heart rate sensor module and the LCD display module.
9. Implement the code to read the heart rate data from the sensor and display it on the LCD display.
10. Upload the code to the Arduino board.
11. Power on the Arduino board and observe the heart rate data being displayed on the LCD module.

### Tips and Considerations
- Make sure to carefully read the datasheets of the heart rate sensor module and the LCD display module to understand their pin configurations.
- Double-check all the connections before powering on the circuit to avoid any potential issues.
- If you encounter difficulties in reading the heart rate data, ensure that the sensor is properly placed on your finger or wrist and that there is good contact between the sensor and your skin.

### Troubleshooting
- If the heart rate data is not being displayed on the LCD module, check the wiring and connections between the Arduino board, heart rate sensor module, and LCD display module.
- Ensure that the libraries for the heart rate sensor module and the LCD display module are properly installed in the Arduino IDE.

### Safety Measures
- Take necessary precautions when handling electronic components to avoid any electrical shocks.
- Do not touch any exposed wires or connections while the circuit is powered on.

### Common Mistakes to Avoid
- Incorrectly connecting the pins of the heart rate sensor module and the LCD display module can lead to errors in data reading and display.
- Neglecting to adjust the contrast of the LCD display using the potentiometer can result in an unreadable display.

### Summary and Key Takeaways
Building a basic cardiac monitor using an Arduino board, heart rate sensor module, and LCD display module is a rewarding project that allows you to monitor your heart rate in real-time. By following the step-by-step procedure outlined in this guide, you can successfully create your own cardiac monitor and gain valuable insights into your cardiovascular health. Remember to exercise caution, double-check connections, and troubleshoot any issues that may arise. Enjoy your new cardiac monitor!
